journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Fracture and effective properties of finite magnetoelectroelastic media

contrib-group.aff: Graduate School at Shenzhen and Center for Composite Materials, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, P.R. China

author-notes.corresp: Baolin Wang, Graduate School at Shenzhen and Center for Composite Materials, Harbin Institute of Technology, 92 Xi Da Zhi Jie, Harbin 150001, P.R. China. Email: wangbl2001@hotmail.com

abstract.p: Magnetoelectroelastic materials are inherently brittle and prone to cracking. It is important to understand how cracks influence the magnetoelectrical coupling properties of the magnetoelectroelastic materials. This article establishes an analytical model for a finite crack in a finite magnetoelectroelastic medium. The stress, electric displacement, and magnetic induction and their intensity factors are obtained by the integral equation technique. The temperature effect is also studied. The effect of cracking on the effective thermomagnetoelectromechanical properties is discussed. In addition, crack is modeled as a notch of finite height to study the effect of the crack-face electric and magnetic boundary condition assumptions on the predicted properties of the magnetoelectroelastic medium.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Magnetoelectroelastic materials possess the features that the application of electric field induces magnetization and magnetic field induces electric polarization. The effects of electromagnetomechanical coupling have been observed in single-phase materials and in composites made of ferroelectric and ferromagnetic phases (Alshits et al., 1992; Vandenbo et al., 1974; Van Run et al., 1974). Such coupling effects are very useful in engineering applications of smart/intelligent materials and structures. Since a broadband magnetoelectric (ME) transducer with a flat frequency response was reported (Bracke and Vliet, 1981), many investigations of ME coupling have been conducted both theoretically and experimentally (Benveniste, 1995; Harshe et al., 1993a, 1993b; Javelined and Harshe, 1994; Nan, 1994). It has been found that composites made of ferroelectric/ferromagnetic phases can exhibit a significant ME coupling effect that is not present in single-phase ferroelectric or ferromagnetic materials (Aboudi, 2001; Pan and Heyliger, 2002). Many investigations of ME coupling have been conducted both theoretically and experimentally. A detailed review of the research topics for the ME materials was given by Fiebig (2005).

Both ferroelectric and ferromagnetic phases in magnetoelectroelastic composites are usually brittle. Cracking or formation of defects in such composites may occur either during fabrication or when subjected to loads in service. Efforts have been made to analyze the behavior of magnetoelectroelastic materials with defects such as cracks, holes, and inclusions (Du et al., 2004; Feng et al., 2005; Gao et al., 2003; Li and Kardomateas, 2007; Soh and Liu, 2005; Su et al., 2007; Zhao et al., 2008; Zhong and Li, 2006). In addition, the effect of imperfect bonding on dynamic properties of piezoelectric/piezomagnetic composites was also studied (Melkumyan and Mai, 2008). Theoretical study of magnetoelectroelastic materials with a single conducting crack was presented by Tian and Rajapakse (2005). A crack near the interface of magnetoelectroelastic bimaterials was investigated by Tian and Gabbert (2005).

In general, the ME coupling coefficient measured in magnetoelectroelastic composites is much lower than that from theoretical prediction. Existing inclusions and/or cracks may alter the overall effective properties and reduce the ME effect of the composite materials considerably. The inclusion problems were solved, and the average fields and effective moduli of nonhomogeneous media with elastic, electric, and magnetic coupling effects were studied (Bichurin and Petrov, 2003; Li and Dunn, 1998a, 1998b; Srinivas et al., 2006; Wang et al., 2005). Micromechanics method was also extensively used to study the effective properties of ME composites with inclusions of piezoelectric and magnetostrictive phases (Huang and Zhou, 2004; Wang and Shen, 2003; Zhong and Sun, 2002). Using the micromechanics method, Srinivas et al. (2006) estimated the properties of multiferroic composites by taking into account the effects of the shape and orientation distribution of the second phase. Exact solutions for three-dimensional, anisotropic magnetoelectroelastic, simply supported and layered rectangular plates under surface and internal loads were obtained by Pan (2001). Wang and Shen (2002) presented a general solution to the three-dimensional problems of the magnetoelectroelastic materials. Chen et al. (2002), Wang et al. (2005), and Bichurin and Petrov (2003) gave the static or low-frequency ME coupling for layered composites. Lee et al. (2005) used finite element method to study the effective properties of an elastic medium with a piezoelectric phase and a piezomagnetic phase embedded. Thermal effects in magnetoelectroelastic materials were also considered by some researchers. For example, Aboudi (2001) carried out a micromechanical analysis of fully coupled electromagnetothermoelastic multiphase composites. Ootao and Tanigawa (2005) investigated multilayered magnetoelectrothermoelastic strip due to unsteady and nonuniform heat supply. Gao et al. (2003) analyzed fully coupled electromagnetothermoelastic medium with collinear permeable cracks.

The above-mentioned studies were mainly conducted for infinitesimal cracks and inclusions in the material. The effect of finite cracking on the effective properties of magnetoelectroelastic materials was rarely reported in publications. To our best knowledge, no study has been conducted for the effect of cracking on the pyroelectric and pyromagnetic properties of the magnetoelectroelastic materials. Motivated by this consideration, this article investigates the overall average properties of the magnetoelectroelastic composites due to finite cracking. Solution method to the finite crack problem in the magnetoelectroelastic media is given, and the magnetoelectromechanical fields are obtained. The effects of crack length and medium size on the overall magnetoelectromechanical properties of the magnetoelectroelastic medium are given. Thermal effect is also considered and the crack tip field intensity factors are also obtained for the finite medium since they are not available in open literature. In addition, the effect of the crack-face electric and magnetic boundary condition assumptions on the predicted properties of the magnetoelectroelastic materials is discussed.

sec.title: Description of the problem
sec.p: Figure 1 shows a magnetoelectroelastic medium with a through height crack. The crack length is 2a. The height of the medium is 2c, and the length of the medium is 2h. The problem is such that all the field variables are only functions of the coordinates (x, z), which are coincident with the principal axes of the material symmetry. Denote the displacement components along the x and z directions as u and w, respectively, the electric potential as ϕ and the magnetic potential as ϕ. The upper border of the medium is subjected to a combination of constant displacement, electric potential, and magnetic potential (w+, ϕ+, and ϕ+). The lower border of the medium is subjected to a combination of constant displacement, electric potential, and magnetic potential (w−, ϕ−, and ϕ−), which is equal to (−w+, −ϕ+, and −ϕ+). As a result, the average applied strain ε0, electric field E0, and magnetic field H0 are ε0 = w+/c, E0 = −ϕ+/c, and H0 = −ϕ+/c, respectively. In addition, the left and right borders of the medium are free from mechanical, electric, and magnetic loads.

caption.p: A through height crack in a finite magnetoelectroelastic medium (c: medium height, a: half crack length, and h: half medium width). The boundary conditions are σxx(±h,z)=σxz(±h,z)=Dx(±h,z)=Bx(±h,z)=0).

sec.title: Basic magnetoelectroelasticity equations
sec.p: The basic expressions of magnetoelectroelasticity have been given by Parton and Kudryavtsev (1988), Nan (1994), Li and Dunn (1998a, 1998b), Aboudi (2001), and so on. The constitutive equations are
where σ, ε, D, E, B, and H are vectors of stress, strain, electric displacement, electric field, magnetic induction, and magnetic field, respectively, defined by
For a magnetoelectroelastic medium whose poling direction coincides with the positive z-axis, the material constant matrices c, e, h, ∈, β, and γ, respectively, have the following forms

where cijkl, ekij, hkij, ∈ij, βij, and γij are elastic coefficients, electromechanical coupling coefficients, magnetomechanical coupling coefficients, dielectric permeability coefficients, ME coupling coefficients, and magnetic permeability coefficients, respectively. The stresses, electric displacements, and the magnetic inductions satisfy the following equilibrium equations

Here, the body force, charge density, and current density are absent. Equations for the displacements, electric potential, and magnetic potential can be established by substituting equations (1) to (3) into equation (4). They can be solved under prescribed magnetoelectromechanical boundary conditions on the border of the medium and the surface of the crack.

sec.title: Modeling of the crack problem
sec.p: For the problem under consideration, the crack surfaces are traction free. Generally, there are two extreme cases for the electromagnetic boundary conditions on the crack faces. One is the electrically and magnetically impermeable crack assumption, and the other is the electrically and magnetically permeable crack assumption. In the case of permeable crack, the crack does not obstruct any electric and magnetic fields, and the electric and magnetic potentials across crack are zero. As a direct result, the permeable crack will have no influence on the ME coupling of the magnetoelectroelastic medium. In the case of impermeable crack, the crack does not allow any penetration of electric flux and magnetic flux through the crack interior. It is expected that this will result in the most severe reduction in the ME coupling effect of the magnetoelectroelastic medium by cracking. More details are given in section “Effect of the medium inside the crack” of this article. For this reason, this article focuses on the impermeable crack problem first. In this situation, the mixed boundary conditions on the cracked plane are stated as follows
and

Because of symmetry, it is sufficient to consider one quarter of the medium, 0 ≤z≤c, 0 ≤x < h. The horizontal displacement, the shear stress σxz, electric displacement component Dx, and magnetic induction Bx vanish at the mid-plane of the medium (i.e. the x = 0 plane). Therefore, we have
In addition, the stress components σxx and σxz, the electric displacement component Dx, and the magnetic induction Bx vanish on right border of the medium (i.e. the x = h plane) so that
The symmetry conditions also imply that
Finally, the loading conditions for the representative element are
The solution of the representative element is expressed in terms of some unknown coefficients. These unknown coefficients are then determined from the boundary conditions of the problem.

sec.title: Magnetoelectroelastic fields
sec.p: The equilibrium equations of magnetoelectroelastic coupling have been given by equation (4). Because of symmetry, the solution of the equilibrium equations can be obtained in a straightforward manner by applying the Fourier transform. Similar to the case of pure elastic materials (Nied, 1987), the solution can be expressed as

in which sn=nπ/c, Fmn are unknown functions of sn, and Gm(s) stand for unknown functions of s. The constant u0 is such that the stress σxx produced by (ε0,E0,andH0) vanishes everywhere inside the medium. With the substitution of equation (10) into the equilibrium equations, it can be seen that the constants aim and parameters λm (m = 1, …, 8) are determined from the following eigenvalue problem

In equation (11), nontrivial ajm (j = 1, …, 4) exists if λm is a root of the determinant. Obviously, there are eight roots for λm. It can be seen that if [λm, (a1m, a2m, a3m, a4m)T] is an eigensolution of equation (11), then [−λm, (−a1m, a2m, a3m, a4m)T] is also an eigensolution of equation (11).

In what follows, the order of roots λm are arranged such that Re(λ1) < 0, Re(λ2) < 0, Re(λ3) < 0, and Re(λ4) < 0, and λ5 = −λ1, λ6 = −λ2, λ7 = −λ3, and λ8 = −λ4. The stresses, electric displacements, and magnetic inductions associated with equation (10) are obtained from the constitutive equations (1) to (3) as follows

in which the constants Cjm (j = 1, …, 7; m = 1, …, 8) are given in Appendix 1, and σ0, D0, and B0 are the equivalent stress, electric displacement, and magnetic induction, respectively, by the applied loads ε0, E0, and H0
where the coefficients with an over bar are listed in Appendix 2.
The unknown coefficients Fmn and Gm involved in the magnetoelectroelastic fields will be determined from the boundary conditions (5) to (9).

sec.title: Satisfying the symmetry and boundary conditions
sec.p: In what follows, the unknown coefficients Fmn and Gm will be expressed in terms of three auxiliary functions (g1, g2, and g3), defined by

By this definition, equation (5b) is satisfied automatically. From the boundary conditions (8) and (9), and with substitution of equation (10) into equation (14), we know that Gm can be expressed in terms of (g1, g2, and g3) as
where Nmk (m = 1, …, 8; k = 1, 2, 3, 4) are known coefficients
and where bmk are the elements of the following matrix
It should be noted that the exponents in equation (16) may be negative, due to the selection of eigenvalues λm with negative real part for m = 1–4.
From the symmetry conditions (6), we know that
From the surface conditions (7), we know that
in which the coefficients δik (i = 1, 2, 3, 4; k = 1, 2, 3) are listed in Appendix 3.
The linear system of algebraic equations (18) and (19) can be used to determine the unknown coefficients Fmn, in terms of the auxiliary functions gk; the result is

where fmnk0(r) are known coefficients, which are given in Appendix 4. Now the problem has been reduced to the determination of the auxiliary functions gk. The crack-face boundary conditions (5a) can be used to solve gk.

sec.title: Singular integral equations
sec.p: From equation (12), and with the substitution of equations (15) and (20), the stress σzz, the electric displacement Dz, and the magnetic induction Bz on the z = 0 plane can be expressed as
where {g} = (g1, g2, g3)T, and the elements in the matrices Ω0 and Ψ0 are
where (i, k = 1, 2, 3).

In order to determine the possible singular behavior of equation (21), the behavior of the kernel ψ0(x, r) at x = r needs to be examined. From equation (16), we know that as s approaches infinity, we have Nmk=bmk and N(m+4)k=0 for (m = 1, 2, 3, 4). In the limit case of infinite s, the team limz→+0∑m=18(1/λm)CimNmkexp(ξz/λm) in equation (23) becomes ∑m=14(1/λm)Cimbmk. Accordingly, equation (23) can be rewritten as
where Λik0=−∑m=14(1/λm)Cimbmk. Equation (24a) can be further simplified to
where Λ0 is a 3 × 3 matrix whose elements are Λik0, and the elements of the matrix Θ0 are
and where (i, k = 1, 2, 3), csch(x) is the hyperbolic cosecant of the elements of x. For c→∞ (infinite medium height) or r→−x, equation (25) gives Θ(x, r) = 0.
Note that equation (21) is valid for x≥a and x<a. For the latter, the crack-face boundary conditions (5a) would give the following integral equations for the auxiliary functions gk(r)
where {p0(x)} = {−σ0, −D0, −B0}, and
is a bounded integral kernel in interval [0, a]. Since the problem is symmetric with respect to x = 0, gk(r) are even functions of r. Thus, equation (26) is equivalent to
The integral equation (28) can be normalized between −1 and 1 with the substitutions of x=x¯a, r=r¯a, and {g(x)}=a{g¯(x¯)}, where a is the half crack length. The normalized integral equation is

To solve the integral equation (29), it is important to realize that the cracks are embedded in the medium (this is unlike the surface or edge crack problem). The solution of equation (29) can be expressed as (Han and Wang, 2005)

where Uj(r¯)=sin[(j+1)arccos(r¯)]/1−r¯2 is the Chebyshev polynomial of the second kind and mkj are unknown coefficients. The odd terms of the Chebyshev polynomial have been omitted here because the problem is symmetric and g¯k(r¯) must be even functions of r¯. After substituting equation (30) into equation (29), and evaluating the finite-part integral given by
we obtain
where the coefficients Ωijk are

in which Hik0 are elements of the matrix H. Equation (32) can be solved by collocation (Han and Wang, 2005), where the roots of the Chebyshev polynomial are used as collocation points for x¯. The field intensity factors for stress k1, electric displacement kD, and magnetic induction kB at the crack tip defined by
can be expressed in terms of the functions mkj by

After determining the coefficients mkj, the crack surface opening displacement g1(x), the electric potential g2(x), and the magnetic potential g3(x) on the surface z = +0 can be obtained from equation (30) as
This completes the solutions for the crack tip field. The stress, electric displacement, and magnetic induction in the cracked medium will be discussed subsequently.

sec.title: Stress, electric displacement, and magnetic induction in the cracked medium
sec.p: The normal stress σzz(x, z), electric displacement Dz(x, z), and magnetic induction Bz(x, z) are important quantities since they may cause crack growth. In addition, these quantities are useful in evaluating the effective properties of the cracked medium. Due to equilibrium, the averages of the stress, the electric displacement, and the magnetic induction should be same for any z. For this, the quantities on the medium surface z = c are given here. Substituting equations (15) and (20) into equation (12a), the stress σzz, electric displacement Dz(x, z), and magnetic induction Bz(x, z) on the z = c plane can be obtained as follows
in which
where the elements in the matrices Πa and Πb are

On the right-hand side of equation (38), the first and the second terms are the contributions due to the finite width and the finite height of the medium, respectively. If the medium is infinity in length (i.e. h>>a), then Πa=0. On the other hand, if the medium is infinity in height (i.e. c>>a), then Πb=0.

sec.title: Analysis results
sec.p: Some numerical results are given for a magnetoelectroelastic composite made of piezoelectric and piezomagnetic phases (Getman, 1994). The effective properties of the magnetoelectroelastic composite are obtained from the micromechanics model given by Getman (1994). The results are as follows:

In sections “Magnetoelectromechanical loads” and “Residual temperature change,” the cases of magnetoelectromechanical loads and a residual temperature change ΔT0 in the medium will be investigated separately. In section “Effect of the medium inside the crack,” the effect of the crack-face electric and magnetic boundary conditions on the effective properties of the magnetoelectroelastic medium is discussed.

sec.title: Magnetoelectromechanical loads
sec.p: Figure 2 plots the stress (σzz) distribution on the top plane of the medium (z = c) for an applied strain ε0, in which ε0=w+/c. Results are normalized with σ0 and are given for h = 2a and 5a, and c = 4a, 6a, and 10a. Because of cracking, there is a significant reduction in the magnitude of the stress on the top surface of the medium. This reflects the decrease of the stiffness of the medium by cracking. The reduction is more pronounced for small values of medium height and medium length than for high values of medium height and medium length. Similar phenomena are observed for the electric displacement distribution for an applied electric field load E0 and for the magnetic induction distribution for an applied magnetic field H0. These phenomena reflect the decreases of the stiffness, dielectric permeability, and magnetic permeability, due to cracking. The equivalent stiffness c¯33, dielectric permeability ∈¯33, and magnetic permeability γ¯33 of the cracked medium, together with the magnetoelectromechanical coupling coefficients, are defined in the following manner
in which a variable with an over bar represents the average of the corresponding quantity at z = c

where the stress σzz(x,c), electric displacement Dz(x,c), and magnetic induction Bz(x,c) are calculated from equation (37). From equation (41), the effective material constants c¯33, e¯33, h¯33, ∈¯33, β¯33, and γ¯33 can be calculated. For example, by applying [ε0,E0,H0]=[1,0,0], equation (41) becomes [σ¯0,D¯0,B¯0]=[c¯33,−e¯33,−h¯33]. Accordingly, [c¯33,−e¯33,−h¯33]=[σ¯0,D¯0,B¯0]. Similarly, by applying [ε0,E0,H0]=[0,1,0], one obtains [−e¯33,∈¯33,β¯33]=[σ¯0,D¯0,B¯0], and by applying [ε0,E0,H0]=[0,0,1], one obtains [−h¯33,β¯33,γ¯33]=[σ¯0,D¯0,B¯0].

caption.p: Stress distribution on the top plane of the medium (y = c) for an applied field ε0 (σ0 is calculated from equation (13) under the conditions E0=0 and H0=0). The results are given for h = 2a and 5a and c = 4a, 6a, and 10a.

sec.p: The results for the stiffness of the cracked medium, after normalized with the stiffness of the uncracked medium, are shown in Figure 3. As expected, the stiffness is a decreasing function of crack length. Specifically, for h = 2a and c = a, the normalized stiffness c¯33 is 0.59, a value of 41% less than the stiffness of the uncracked medium. Such a reduction is very pronounced, indicating the importance of the effect of cracking on the overall properties of the medium. Similar tendency is found for equivalent dielectric permeability ∈¯33 and magnetic permeability γ¯33. Thus, cracking is a key factor in changing the overall properties of the magnetoelectroelastic materials.

caption.p: Variation of equivalent stiffness c¯33 with crack length where c330=c¯33=c33−c132/c11.

sec.p: As a type of functional material, ME media are mainly used to create the ME coupling effect, that is, by applying a magnetic field to the medium to create an output of electric field or vice versa. Therefore, investigation of the coupling coefficient between the magnetic field and the electric displacement after cracking is important. By analyzing equation (13), we know that in the absence of applied strain load, an applied magnetic field H0 would produce an electric displacement D0=β¯33H0 in the uncracked medium, in which β¯33=β33+e31h31/c11 is the coupling coefficient between the magnetic field and the electric displacement for the uncracked medium. After cracking, the value of the coupling coefficient β¯33 will become β¯33, which is calculated from equation (41). Variation of β¯33 with medium length and height is plotted in Figure 4. Considerable reduction in the ME coupling is observed, especially for large crack size in the medium.

caption.p: Variation of equivalent magnetoelectric coupling coefficient β¯33 with crack length where β330=β¯33=β33+e31h31/c11.

sec.p: With the model developed, it is also possible to obtain the field intensity factor at the crack tip. As an example, Figure 5 plots the normalized stress intensity factor k1 for an equivalent applied stress σ0, which is calculated from equation (13). It is observed that the stress intensity factor increases with the increase in medium height c but decreases with the increase in medium length h. Note that when c/a = 1 and h/a≥ 1.5, the stress intensity factor k1≈0.58σ0πa, a value that is about 58% of the stress intensity factor for a single isolated crack in infinite medium. Similar facts are found for the electric displacement intensity factor and the magnetic induction intensity factor. After the field intensity factors are obtained, the near-crack tip quantities can be expressed as those given by Wang and Mai (2003).

caption.p: Stress intensity factor as a function of the medium height and length (k0=σ0πa, where σ0 is calculated from equation (13) under the conditions E0=0 and H0=0).

sec.title: Residual temperature change
sec.p: Thermal analyses for magnetoelectroelastic medium are very important in industrial applications. Many structural components containing magnetoelectroelastic materials are subjected to thermal loads. Typical examples are aerospace structures operating in cooling and/or heating environments and smart/intelligent materials sensing temperature changes. Thus, the prediction of fracture of magnetoelectroelastic materials under thermal loading is important. Before going to the analysis of the crack problem, we identify the thermally induced magnetoelectroelastic fields in the absence of any cracks. Once these fields are obtained for uncracked medium, the crack problem can be solved by a superposition technique, that is, the equal and opposite values of the stress, electric displacement, and magnetic induction are added to the crack faces to form the equivalent external loads, and the crack problem is solved using the method described in section “Magnetoelectroelastic fields.” Referring to Appendix 5, if the entire system is subjected to a residual temperature decrease of ΔT0 (then T=−ΔT0 in equation (60)), the equivalent magnetoelectroelastic loads for the uncracked medium can be calculated from

in which the parameters with an over bar have been given in Appendices 2 and 4. Since the case of magnetoelectromechanical loads has been considered in section “Magnetoelectromechanical loads,” we only need to consider the case of pure temperature load here. Thus, the magnetoelectromechanical loads ε0, E0, and H0 are zero in equation (43). The equivalent magnetoelectroelastic loads σ0, D0, and B0 will be applied to the analytical model described in section “Magnetoelectroelastic fields” to obtain the stress σzz(x,c), the electric displacement Dz(x,c), and the magnetic induction Bz(x,c) on the z = c plane. Due to cracking, the material properties of thermal stress coefficient λ33, pyroelectric τ3, and the pyromagnetic coefficient ρ3 will change. The equivalent stiffness thermal stress coefficient λ¯33, pyroelectric coefficient τ¯3, and pyromagnetic coefficient ρ¯3 are defined in the following manner

where σ¯0, D¯0, and B¯0 are the averages of σzz(x,c), Dz(x,c), and Bz(x,c), respectively. They are calculated according to equation (42). Clearly, from equation (42), we know that all of the thermal stress coefficient λ¯33, pyroelectric coefficient τ¯3, and pyromagnetic coefficient ρ¯3 contribute to the values of σ¯0, D¯0, and B¯0, respectively.

To calculate the equivalent thermal stress coefficient λ¯33, pyroelectric coefficient τ¯3, and pyromagnetic coefficient ρ¯3, we need the original values of the thermal properties of the materials (those are as follows: thermal stress coefficient λ¯33, pyroelectric coefficient τ¯3, and pyromagnetic coefficient ρ¯3). To our best knowledge, no such values are available for any specific magnetoelectroelastic materials in the literature. However, we expect that, comparing to λ¯33, contribution of the coupling coefficients τ¯3 and ρ¯3 to the stress for the cracked medium is not significant. Thus, in calculating the stress σ¯0, the coefficients τ¯3 and ρ¯3 can be neglected. Similarly, in calculating the electric displacement D¯0, the coefficients λ¯33 and ρ¯3 can be neglected, and in calculating the magnetic induction B¯0, the coefficients λ¯33 and τ¯3 can be neglected. In this situation, the equivalent material properties after cracking (λ¯33, τ¯3, and ρ¯3) can be obtained from equation (44). Variation of the equivalent thermal stress coefficient λ¯33 with the crack size is plotted in Figure 6 for selected values of the medium height. Evidently, cracking has a strong effect on the equivalent thermal stress coefficient. λ¯33 decreases rapidly with the normalized crack length. For a medium of thinner height, the reduction in the equivalent thermal stress coefficient is more pronounced. This is particularly obvious for longer crack. Dependency of the equivalent pyroelectric coefficient τ¯3 and pyromagnetic coefficient ρ¯3 on the crack length is not plotted here since it is similar to that of the equivalent thermal stress coefficient λ¯33.

caption.p: Effect of cracking on the equivalent thermal stress coefficient λ¯33.

sec.title: Effect of the medium inside the crack
sec.p: In the main text of the article, the crack is assumed to be electrically and magnetically impermeable, so that the electric displacement and magnetic inductions inside the crack are zero. In engineering practice, however, a flaw in a material rather likes a notch with a finite height (see Figure 7). Accordingly, the electric permeability and magnetic permeability of the medium inside the notch (air or vacuum) will contribute to the response of the magnetoelectroelastic medium. As a result, the electric displacement and the magnetic induction inside the notch do not vanish, which are denoted as d0 and b0, respectively.

caption.p: An notch at the center of a finite magnetoelectroelastic medium (c: medium height, a: half crack (notch) length, h: half medium width, and δ0: maximum gap height of the notch).

sec.p: Now consider the effect of notch on the response of the ME medium. Suppose that the height δ of the notch is sufficiently small, except near the tip of the notch, the gradient of crack opening along the crack is small. The electric field E and the magnetic field H along the z direction inside the notch can be obtained from
Accordingly, the normal components of the electric displacement and magnetic induction vectors inside the crack are

respectively, in which ∈0 and γ0 are the electric permeability and magnetic permeability of the medium inside the crack (usually air or vacuum), respectively. The linear system of algebraic equations (28) is still valid, provided that the load vector becomes {p0(x)} = {−σ0, d0−D0, b0−B0}. Accordingly, equation (32) needs to be solved together with equation (46) to obtain the unknowns (g1, g2, g3) and (d0, b0). We further suppose the notch profile is elliptic so that δ(x)=δ0a1−x¯2, in which δ0a is the largest distance between the upper and lower faces of the notch. With the expression of (30), it follows from equation (46) that (d0, b0) can be written as
As a result, equation (32) becomes

in which x∈[0,a]. After solving equations (48a) to (48c), the fully field solution can be obtained. It can be seen that if δ0 is zero such that the upper and lower surfaces of the notch are in ideal contact, the electric potential and magnetic potential jumps across the notch must be zero for finite values of electric and magnetic fields inside the notch (see equation (45)). This corresponds to the fully permeable crack. On the other hand, if δ0 is sufficiently large, the electric displacement and magnetic induction inside the notch approach zero for finite electric potential and magnetic potential jumps across the notch (see equation (46)). This corresponds to the fully impermeable crack.

From numerical results, it is found that notch profile has little effect on the crack tip stress intensity factor and the equivalent stiffness c¯33. However, the gap height is shown to have a major influence on the electromagnetic field intensity factors at the notch tip and the equivalent ME coupling coefficient β¯33. Some sample results for the notch solution of β¯33 are presented in Figure 8. Clearly, β¯33 decreases dramatically with the increasing value of the gap height δ0. When δ0 is zero, the result for the fully permeable crack is retained and cracking has no effect on the equivalent ME coupling coefficient β¯33. When δ0 is sufficiently large, the equivalent ME coupling coefficient β¯33 becomes the same as that of the impermeable crack solution. The idealization of the fully permeable assumption is only reasonable for extremely small notch aspect ratios. It seems that β¯33 for the fully impermeable crack is still not retained for a notch aspect ratio of 0.1 or greater. Therefore, the knowledge of notch width-to-length ratio is essential for obtaining the correct β¯33. The impermeable crack assumption predicts the most severe reduction in the ME coupling.

caption.p: Dependency of the equivalent magnetoelectric coupling coefficient β¯33 on the notch height-to-length ratio (β330=β¯33=β33+e31h31/c11).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Magnetoelectroelastic materials are usually developed in the form of composites made of ferroelectric and ferromagnetic phases. Both ferroelectric and ferromagnetic phases are inherently brittle and prone to cracking. This article investigated the effect of a crack on the responses and the overall properties of a finite magnetoelectroelastic material medium. A general analytical model for the magnetoelectromechanical coupling is established. The effect of crack size and the crack-face electromagnetic boundary conditions is studied. Dependencies of the effective stiffness, dielectric permeability, magnetic permeability, ME coupling coefficient, pyroelectric coefficient, and pyromagnetic coefficient on the medium size are discussed. The crack tip field intensity factors are also investigated and are shown graphically. The following conclusions can be drawn:

list-item.p: The crack-face electromagnetic boundary condition assumption has a strong effect on the equivalent values of the ME coupling coefficient, pyroelectric coefficient, and pyromagnetic coefficient of the magnetoelectroelastic materials. The impermeable crack results in the most severe reduction in these coefficients. It means that considering the impermeable crack alone can give us the robust design for the fabrication.
The crack-face electromagnetic boundary condition assumption has little influence on the equivalent stiffness coefficient and thermal stress coefficient.
The knowledge of the crack size is essential for the correct prediction of the thermomagnetoelectromechanical properties of the magnetoelectroelastic materials by cracking.

The magnitude of the residual thermal stress, electric displacement, and magnetic induction medium depends on a number of parameters. Among these parameters, the thermal stresses, the thermal electric displacements, and the thermal magnetic inductions in the medium are controlled by the equivalent parameters λ¯33, τ¯3, and ρ¯3, which have been identified and given in equations (43) and (61).

It is well known that in the case of stress/electric displacement/magnetic induction loads on the medium boundaries, the normalized stress intensity factors will always be greater than 1.0. However, if the applied loads are the displacement/electric potential/magnetic potential loads on the medium boundaries (such as considered in the current article), the normalized stress intensity factor can be greater or lesser than 1.0, depending on the values of the medium height and width. The stress intensity factor increases with the decrease in medium width h but increases with the increase in medium height c.

sec.p: During the reviewing process, one referee argued the originality of the article from the articles of Wang and Han (2010a, 2010b) and Wang et al. (2011a, 2001b). Clearly, the article of Wang and Han (2010b) is for antiplane (mode III) crack problem. The current article studies the more important mode I crack problem, which is more useful for engineering practice but is more difficult to solve. In addition, the thermal stress and the effect of medium inside the crack are also considered in the current article, which were not studied in any available literature. Except for the article of Wang and Han (2010b), the other articles did not analyze the electromagnetic coupling at all.
